title: Staying Engaged
description: Explore how you stay present versus withdraw during conflict

questions.text: I can stay present during difficult conversations without shutting down.

therapeutic.rationale: Shutting down during conflict—stonewalling—leaves partners feeling abandoned. Staying present, even when it's hard, shows commitment to working through issues together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner shuts down, explore what triggers the withdrawal. Overwhelm? Self-protection? Understanding the cause helps address it with compassion.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to stay present creates complete conversations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you shut down during conflict? What helps you stay engaged?

questions.text: I feel my partner's presence with me even during hard conversations.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling your partner stay engaged during conflict—not checking out or walking away—provides security that you can work through things together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't experience engagement, explore what disengagement looks like. Physical leaving? Emotional withdrawal? Identifying it helps address it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual engagement during conflict creates partnership in problem-solving.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner show engagement during conflict? When do they disengage?

questions.text: When I feel overwhelmed, I can ask for a break without abandoning the conversation.

therapeutic.rationale: Strategic breaks differ from abandonment. Asking for a break with a plan to return shows care for both yourself and the conversation.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If breaks feel like abandonment to one partner, establish a break protocol. 'I need 20 minutes, then I'll come back' creates safety.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ability to take healthy breaks without abandoning creates sustainable conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you handle overwhelm during conflict? Do breaks help?

questions.text: Neither of us uses silence as a weapon.

therapeutic.rationale: Silence can be a pause or a punishment. Using silence to punish—the cold shoulder, refusing to engage—creates insecurity and damages trust.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner experiences weaponized silence, name it directly. The silent partner may not realize how their withdrawal is landing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual commitment to engaged silence (pausing) over punishing silence creates safety.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Is silence ever used as punishment between you? What does that feel like?

questions.text: We can have hard conversations without one of us completely checking out.

therapeutic.rationale: Complete checkout during conflict leaves one partner alone with the issue. Staying present—even partially—shows the relationship matters more than discomfort.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner checks out, explore together what would help them stay. Shorter conversations? Different approach? Lower intensity?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual presence during hard conversations enables resolution.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps both of you stay present during difficult conversations?
